awd_titl_txt: DOE Support for the Climate Variability and Predictability (CLIVAR) Project Office Activities, 2009-2014
awd_abstract_narration:
The International and U.S. CLIVAR (CLImate VARiability and predictability) Project Offices (USCLIVAR PO) provide critical infrastructure support leading to the coordinated planning and implementation of U.S. and international research activities that address CLIVAR goals which are to: 

- describe and understand the physical processes responsible for climate variability and predictability on seasonal, inter-annual, decadal, and centennial time-scales, through the collection and analysis of observations and the development and application of models of the coupled climate system, in cooperation with other relevant climate-research and observing programs; 
- extend the record of climate variability over the time-scales of interest through the assembly of quality-controlled paleoclimatic and instrumental data sets; 
- extend the range and accuracy of seasonal to inter-annual climate prediction through the development of global coupled predictive models; and 
- understand and predict the response of the climate system to increases of radiatively active gases and aerosols and to compare these predictions to the observed climate record in order to detect the anthropogenic modification of the natural climate signal. 

This award supports the USCLIVAR PO staffing, travel by U.S. scientists to participate in CLIVAR meetings, funds for open science workshops, and costs associated with outreach and communications necessary to communicate CLIVAR findings and opportunities. 

The intellectual merit of this proposal enables development of new community-driven scientific plans, coordination of research activity implementation, and provides assistance to U.S. research program agencies so their programs more effectively contribute towards mutually agreeable challenges. 

The broader impacts resulting from this proposed activity are that the scientific community identifies emerging climate science research topics of interest to the community, sponsoring agencies, and to the nation; assesses current activities to identify program gaps; and catalyzes (interagency sponsored) research activities. 

Complementary co-support is provided by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and the Department of Energy.

por.por_cntn:
The US Climate Variability and Predictability (CLIVAR) Program is a US federally-sponsored research program to advance understanding and prediction of climate variability and change on timescales from intraseasonal to centennial, through observations and models, with an emphasis on the role of the ocean and its interaction with other elements of the Earth system. The US CLIVAR Project Office, operated through the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research, provides the staff, meeting, and travel support to enable science community planning and implementation of climate research activities, interagency coordination of research calls, and collaboration among climate scientists. Specifically, the Department of Energy support of the Project Office since 2013 has sponsored the travel of US scientists to participate in meetings of the US CLIVAR scientific steering committee, its three implementation panels, and several topical working groups and workshops.

In 2013, the steering committee and panels produced a new science plan that lays out goals, strategies, and research challenges to guide implementation within the US climate science community of research activities for the decade ahead. Since 2014, annual meetings of the steering committee and panels have assessed the current capabilities and assessed future needs for climate observations, monitoring, analysis, process understanding, model improvement, and evaluation of simulations and predictions of the global climate system, with additional efforts to develop an effective interface with the applications of climate information for practical decision support. Their conclusions and actions are summarized in annual program reports, edited by the Project Office and available on the program website.

US CLIVAR working groups are comprised of 12-24 scientists organized for a limited 2-3 year lifetime to undertake focused activities to advance science within the broader community on a US CLIVAR-relevant topic. The working group on El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) Diversity evaluated the state of understanding differences among ENSO events and their teleconnections, sorting out the characterization of these differences, and concluding that the physical processes underlying different “types” of events are not completely distinct and therefore can be viewed as the diverse expression of a complex set of processes. The Eastern Tropical Ocean Synthesis working group assessed recent improvements and common biases in the 5th Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) model simulations for the eastern tropical Pacific and Atlantic basins, identifying persistent errors and their underlying mechanisms, particularly for the southeast Atlantic, where the most pronounced sea surface temperature biases are found. The Hurricane working group organized and analyzed experiments using 12 climate models, exploring their ability to reproduce observed tropical cyclone metrics and the sensitivity of model response to changes in sea surface temperature. The Extremes working group developed and demonstrated the utility of techniques characterizing large-scale meteorological patterns to understand five-day extremes in temperature and precipitation over North America and assessing model representation of them. The working group on Greenland Ice Sheet-Ocean Interactions developed a cross-disciplinary synthesis of the state of knowledge on Greenland Ice Sheet mass loss and the relevant mechanisms and forcings affecting glacial retreat, identifying gaps in understanding of mechanisms and approaches to address them. The Southern Ocean working group developed and applied metrics evaluating CMIP5 experiment data sets, investigating changes in heat and carbon storage in the Southern Ocean.
